column4: There are files in ~/.local/share/gvfs-metadata that seem to indicate info about the samba network drive I have connected to.  I would like to read them so I can find the actual bash address for that samba connection.  But when I open the files in gedit ... I get an encoding error.
How do I discover the bash address of the samba connection?
yes I want to write a bash script to copy files to the attached samba share folder
but in .local/share/gvfs-metadata there are alot of files that reference the samba share by name
maybe I should unmount it through Nautilus.  That is how I had mounted them
how do I mount a samba share through bash then?
you need to add -o username=<your username> if your windows username is not the same as your Ubuntu username
you need smbfs package installed for mount to work, run sudo apt-get install smbfs
oh ok, you can always try IP, well there is a way to use NMBD to resolve short names, but thats another story
you can add the line to /etc/fstab if it needs password you would have to enter the password there in plaintext
I'm wondering if there's a way to do that requires a user input of the password?
I never tried it, but I would guess it would ask for the password at boot if you dont enter it in fstab
